--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <blue5432@y...> wrote:
> 
> Basically, either because a single individual starts a
> new species, or due to selection, a species is reduced
> to only one member before the reproduction phase,
> often there are species with only one individual.
> 
> How do you handle reproduction for a species with only
> one member?  Just clone it?  In Ken's original
> implementation there's a very small interspecies
> mating rate, which won't apply most of the time.  I
> believe Ken said that he simply used a clone in this
> case, but I was wondering if anyone else handled this
> differently (perhaps allowing the lone individual to
> mate with a random individual from the last species it
> belonged to, or something).
> 

I should clarify a couple things about the way I
handled speciation.  There are two important properties
of a species: 1) How many members it contains in
the current generation and 2) How many *offspring* it
is allotted in the next generation.

Item 2 is more important for the purposes of reproduction.
That is because even if there is only one member in
the current generation, as long as it is allotted several
offspring in the next generation, there is room to
clone *and* to create mutated offspring as well,
i.e., there is room for exploration.

So here's how I did it:  If a species is alotted at least 
5 offspring (called expected_offspring in my implementation),
then its champion is cloned.  So if there is only one 
member, it will be cloned.  However, it then has at least
4 more offspring remaining, and these are *not* clones.  They
will generally be mutations of the lone member.
However, if the species is allotted 5 or fewer offspring,
there will be no clone whatsoever, and the lone member
likely will be mutated into something else.  

But that makes sense because if the species is not allotted
some minimum number of offspring, then it probably isn't
good enough to deserve to be cloned, since it's not very
promising anyway.  Keep in mind that fitness sharing ensures
that even a species with a single member gets fair chance
to be allotted offspring.  In fact, allotted offspring is
not correlated with the current species size.

Of course, there is a question where you want to set the 
threshold.   Maybe less or more than 5...though it probably 
doesn't matter that much.  

Perhaps more interesting would be to
up the chances of an interspecies mating for species with
only one current member, as Derek suggested.  That wouldn't 
change the cloning criteria (e.g., greater than 5 alotted 
offspring), but it would mean that for those that weren't
cloned, they have a chance of being more than mere mutations
of the current champion.  However, although this idea
may be worth exploring, it doesn't matter that much since
in the next generation, the species will have grown if
it was promising, and mating will begin to happen anyway.

ken
